holidays.name: International Museum Day
holidays.description: A day to raise awareness about museums and their role in cultural exchange, enrichment of cultures, and development of mutual understanding.
holidays.origin: Established by the International Council of Museums (ICOM) in 1977 to promote the importance of museums worldwide.
holidays.funFact: Each year International Museum Day has a different theme, encouraging museums globally to create unique events and exhibits!

holidays.name: No Dirty Dishes Day
holidays.description: A fun, lighthearted day that encourages everyone to tackle that growing pile of dishes and celebrate the satisfaction of a clean kitchen.
holidays.origin: An informal observance created by cleaning enthusiasts and social media to motivate people to stay on top of household chores.
holidays.funFact: No Dirty Dishes Day is often celebrated by challenging friends and family to see who can clean their dishes the fastest!

holidays.name: National Bike to Work Day (USA)
holidays.description: A day urging commuters to pedal their way to work to promote fitness, reduce pollution, and enjoy a change of pace.
holidays.origin: Part of National Bike Month in the United States, started in 1956 by the League of American Bicyclists.
holidays.funFact: Cities often organize group rides and offer free bike tune-ups on this day to encourage participation.

holidays.name: Vesak (sometimes falls on May 18)
holidays.description: A major Buddhist festival celebrating the birth, enlightenment, and death of Buddha, marked with colorful processions and lanterns.
holidays.origin: An ancient tradition honoring Gautama Buddha, celebrated differently across Buddhist countries according to the lunar calendar.
holidays.funFact: Millions of Buddhists worldwide release lanterns into the sky on Vesak, creating luminous night spectacles.
